Sigh, before you reply again, please just read. My issue isn't with charging, it's that they at least appear to be charging a flat fee for the right to climb regardless of services used or not used that is revenue generating. My point was, and you'd get this if you actually read my original comment at any point, was that they should definitely **BE ABLE TO CHARGE FOR COSTS INCURRED**, but I dislike the idea of them charging a flat fee, again regardless of actual costs, much less them claiming the right of gatekeeper based on skill or any other criteria they might have (including, as you mentioned above stopping there from being "too many" climbers) unilaterally.

Again I'll tell you to read my damn original comment.
If there are costs involved...charge for those
You mean the ones that they carry all the time regardless?

Last I heard, mountains don't have to be funded. Read my post, since apparently you didn't read it thoroughly. I'll quote myself on the relevant portions though, for your benefit.
If there are costs involved, such as for base camps, rescues, and garbage pickup, then charge for those
...
The fee, if any, just for the right to ascend should be solely for unavoidable and shared costs, such as garbage pickup and base camps.
By just for the right to ascend, I meant above and beyond fees for services used, such as base camps, and thus I continue with:
Any services above and beyond that should be charged on an as/if used basis.

Because all the fictional unarmed security guards were busy? As far as I can tell, they only have one kind of security guard at the arboretum, so unless the guard pulled their gun or something, that part of it, if not the entire thing, is a total non-story.

This guy is an absolute idiot, but I find it very uncomfortable that a government can take a natural wonder like Everest and enforce a fee for its use. If there are costs involved, such as for base camps, rescues, and garbage pickup, then charge for those, but charging a prohibitively large fee, with a qualification check, solely on the basis of the right to climb strikes me as going too far. The fee, if any, just for the right to ascend should be solely for unavoidable and shared costs, such as garbage pickup and base camps. Any services above and beyond that should be charged on an as/if used basis.
In terms of protecting Everest from inexperienced and unprepared climbers, I take the very strong point of view that if idiots want to kill themselves, they should be allowed to. People haven't stopped trying to climb mountains because people die doing it and they aren't going to stop now regardless of whether Nepal actively tries to lower the number of deaths or not.
And yet the ratio hovers at around 75, where is the justice in the world. Even with this price drop, I'm wishing I had sold some silver and bought an ounce of gold when I had the chance.

Not the OP, but if you're a Mac and/or iOS user I would strongly recommend [Deliveries for Mac](https://junecloud.com/software/mac/deliveries.html) and [Deliveries for iOS](https://junecloud.com/software/iphone/deliveries.html). They can be set to sync between the two either via their own system or iCloud and have support for pretty much every US and international carrier.

Am I the only person not looking forward to this movie? Maybe it's partially that I know the history, but this strikes me as a movie that is going to be 3/4 random slaughter with a few intertwined main character stories thrown in with near death experiences for the main characters while their friends/cohorts die all around them. Towards the end there will be a turnaround where the characters coming to the rescue pick up the surviving characters, including the major characters we now know about both on the rescuers' and the soldiers' sides, and it will end with a text piece, or perhaps a voiceover about heroism.
It's not just knowing the history though, I enjoyed Saving Private Ryan and plenty of other pseudo-historical, plus several much more historical, large movies.

I liked him as a character, but having him both be the movie's big bad and especially having him having killed Quill's mother was just stupid and went too far IMO, especially given the time and effort expended on exposition. IMO this just shows how screwed up universities' claims towards student and faculty IP are. It's fair that the university should get something if their equipment, paid time, and/or IP owned by the university is used. Much of of the time the agreements that faculty or students either are forced to sign or are defacto held to as policy (even if not individually/specifically signed to, such as part of a code of conduct) are ridiculous and extortionate.

The poultry industry, if not the meat industry as a whole, is going to lurch from one scandal to the next until consumers' eating habits change. The reason that these birds are bred and fed to be overweight isn't just that they can get more money per bird (although that's certainly part of it). It's also because consumers want to buy large chickens, or large pieces of chicken, from their grocery stores and restaurants. It has become an expectation.

When it is twice the price of the previous rounds in the series and they are only doing it because they have a short window where they can and ~~idiots~~ people will still pay, then yes, yes you can and IMO you should blame them.

IMO reputable coin companies don't pull shit like this. I have heard anectdotally that other companies raise their prices based on availability and demand, and I don't doubt that they due, within reason, but I have yet to see, or be mentioned here, an actual example of Provident, APMEX, or one of the other major sellers **doubling** the price of a round, especially a single round in the middle of a series, and I doubt there is one. Everyone is entitled to their opinion, but the fact that they charged twice the price of the previous rounds in series, for no other reason than because they could, is IMO the icing on the cake that makes this pretty damn despicable. It also makes the people who paid that price suckers who overpaid (as is their right, of course). If something, anything, such as the mintage, had changed then it might be a different story, but this can't be excused as anything but greed and hubris. Hopefully enough people agree that it will bite BGASC in the ass, although the fact that most people here are "silver whores" (another commenter's term, not mine) does not give me hope that they'll be hurt by this.
See my reply above. After the preorder they were selling them for ~$95, which is why I am saying **fuck BGASC.**

They were selling them at ~$95 after the preorder, which is totally disconnected from spot price and from what could be considered a reasonable premium when compared to the other rounds in the same set.

I ordered from SGB because they weren't trying to gouge me and I waited (BGASC was the cheapest initially, but their price was still ridiculous). Free shipping was definitely a factor in me choosing to buy more now, but I bought more than I would have otherwise, even with the free shipping, to reward them (and because I'm a silver addict).
I'll give silver dealers a lot of leeway and a lot of slack when it comes to honest mistakes or issues, but this was nakedly taking advantage of the fact that they had a period where they were the exclusivivity to charge well above what would otherwise be "fair," in effect in-line with the price the previous prices in the set sold for. I hold no I'll will to people who paid that price, other than chuckling at how much they overpaid. I do however hold it against the seller and this was unethical on their part after a reasonable expectation of price existed from the previous rounds. That being said, you are wrong, they could be much lower than any competitor and they'll still never get a cent of my money, and in addition I will publicly denounce them as a shady and unscrupulous seller to anyone who will listen.

Add in a bunch of suddenly destitute royals (the immediate royal family would be OK, but some of the outliers might be hurt) and it would be absolutely nuts.
